meanings.definition: (verb) to gradually deteriorate or decline in quality or strength
meanings.sent1: The old house began to decay over time, losing its charm.
meanings.sent2: If you leave food out for too long, it will decay and become unsafe to eat.
meanings.sent3: The forgotten sandwich in the lunchbox started to decay, much to the dismay of its owner.
meanings.sent4: Neglect can cause relationships to decay slowly, like rust eating away at metal.
meanings.sent5: The once vibrant flowers decayed into a wilted mess, showing the passage of time.

meanings.definition: (noun) the process of rotting or decomposing
meanings.sent1: The decay of the fallen leaves provided nutrients for the soil.
meanings.sent2: The smell of decay filled the air in the damp forest.
meanings.sent3: The scientist studied the decay of organic matter to understand the ecosystem better.
meanings.sent4: The decay of the old tree trunk created a home for insects and small animals.
meanings.sent5: The decay of the fruit attracted a swarm of flies, creating a buzzing cloud around it.

meanings.definition: (adjective) in a state of decline or deterioration
meanings.sent1: The abandoned building had a decayed roof and crumbling walls.
meanings.sent2: The once bustling street was now quiet and decayed, with boarded-up shops.
meanings.sent3: The decayed bridge creaked ominously as the wind blew through its rusted metal beams.
meanings.sent4: The decayed bookshelves in the library were filled with dusty, forgotten books.
meanings.sent5: The decayed mansion stood as a haunting reminder of its former grandeur, now lost to time.
